para.sentence: The arclength s of the ellipse x=a\sin\phi,y=b\cos\phi, , if 0\leq\phi\leq 2\pi, with a>b , is given by s=a\int_{0}^{\phi}\sqrt{1-k^{2}{\sin^{2}}\theta}\mathrm{d}\theta.
Cancellation on the second right-hand side of (19.30.3) can be avoided by use of (19.25.10).
The length of the ellipse is L(a,b)=4aE\left(k\right)=8aR_{G}\left(0,b^{2}/a^{2},1\right)=8\!R_{G}\left(0,a ^{2},b^{2}\right)=8abR_{G}\left(0,a^{-2},b^{-2}\right), showing the symmetry in a and b.
Approximations and inequalities for L(a,b) are given in §19.9(i).
Let a^{2} and b^{2} be replaced respectively by a^{2}+\lambda and b^{2}+\lambda , where \lambda\in(-b^{2},\infty) , to produce a family of confocal ellipses.

As \lambda increases, the eccentricity k decreases and the rate of change of arclength for a fixed value of \phi is given by \frac{\partial s}{\partial(1/k)}=\sqrt{a^{2}-b^{2}}F\left(\phi,k\right)=\sqrt{ a^{2}-b^{2}}R_{F}\left(c-1,c-k^{2},c\right), if k^{2}=(a^{2}-b^{2})/(a^{2}+\lambda), c={\csc^{2}}\phi.
The arclength s of the hyperbola x=a\sqrt{t+1},y=b\sqrt{t}, , if 0\leq t<\infty, is given by s=\frac{1}{2}\int_{0}^{y^{2}/b^{2}}\sqrt{\frac{(a^{2}+b^{2})t+b^{2}}{t(t+1)}} \mathrm{d}t.

From (19.29.7), with a_{\delta}=1 and b_{\delta}=0 , s=\tfrac{1}{2}I(\mathbf{e}_{1})=-\tfrac{1}{3}a^{2}b^{2}R_{D}\left(r,r+b^{2}+a^ {2},r+b^{2}\right)+y\sqrt{\frac{r+b^{2}+a^{2}}{r+b^{2}}}, if r=b^{4}/y^{2}.
For s in terms of E\left(\phi,k\right) , F\left(\phi,k\right) , and an algebraic term, see Byrd and Friedman (1971, p. 3).
SeeCarlson (1977b, Ex. 9.4-1 and (9.4-4)) for arclengths of hyperbolas and ellipses in terms of R_{-a} that differ only in the sign of b^{2}.

For 0\leq\theta\leq\tfrac{1}{4}\pi , the arclength s of Bernoulli’s lemniscate r^{2}=2a^{2}\cos\left(2\theta\right), if 0\leq\theta\leq 2\pi, is given by s=2a^{2}\int_{0}^{r}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{4a^{4}-t^{4}}}=\sqrt{2a^{2}}R_{F} \left(q-1,q,q+1\right), if q=2a^{2}/r^{2}=\sec\left(2\theta\right), or equivalently, s=aF\left(\phi,1/\sqrt{2}\right), if \phi=\operatorname{arcsin}\sqrt{2/(q+1)}=\operatorname{arccos}\left(\tan\theta\right).
The perimeter length P of the lemniscate is given by P=4\sqrt{2a^{2}}R_{F}\left(0,1,2\right)=\sqrt{2a^{2}}\times 5.24411\;51\ldots= 4aK\left(1/\sqrt{2}\right)=a\times 7.41629\;87\dots.
For other plane curves with arclength representable by an elliptic integral see Greenhill (1892, p. 190) and Bowman (1953, pp. 32–33).
